awd_abstract_narration:
Award: DMS 1615056, Principal Investigator: James F. Davis

Major branches of theoretical mathematics include topology, algebra, geometry, analysis, and combinatorics.  This project weaves these various threads together.  The major focus is the study of manifolds, which are sets of points locally modeled on Euclidean space.  Sample manifolds in dimension 2 are given by a plane, the surface of a torus, and the surface of a sphere.  However manifolds exist in all dimensions, and their consideration leads to a rich variety of examples and uses a rich variety of tools.  This project focuses on manifolds which are analytically simple but topologically complex. The connection between the disparate fields mentioned above means that one can use topology as a oracle, producing interesting questions, examples, and research in other areas of theoretical mathematics. Manifold theory connects with most areas of mathematics, as well as physical phenomena such as cosmology, string theory, and classical and quantum mechanics.

The principal investigator proposes six projects.  The first is the bordism of L2-acyclic manifolds.  This connects with low-dimensional topology (knot concordance), with algebra (Hilberts 17th problem and the Witt group of function fields), with high-dimensional topology (a new form of surgery theory), and analysis (amenable groups and L2-betti numbers). The second gives a systematic approach to topological equivariant rigidity, using tools from surgery theory, stratified spaces, algebraic K-and L-theory, and the Farrell-Jones Conjecture.  The third is to study and apply combinatorial characteristic classes based on oriented matroids.  The fourth is the Nielsen Realization question, where progress in now possible due to the Farrell-Jones conjecture and the understanding of manifolds whose fundamental groups are infinite with torsion.  The fifth is foundational work in algebraic L-theory, in particular the computation of the L-theory of the polynomial ring in n variables with integral coefficients and the group ring of a free product of groups.  The sixth is to study Brieskorn manifolds produced by algebraic geometry, and, in turn, to use algebraic geometry to study these manifolds.  These problems are all interrelated with each other; the basic theme being classification of manifolds, their bundles, and their symmetries.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant funded successful research in several areas of theoretical mathematics: geometric topology, combinatorics, and homological algebra.   Some of the funded research has already been published and some of it is in the process of being prepared for publication.   

 

The research in geometric topology is connected with manifold theory: both high and low-dimensional manifolds.   The work on high-dimensional manifold is joint with Wolfgang Lueck; one paper has been published in the prestigious journal Communication on Pure and Applied Mathematics.  We have a second paper on the Nielsen Realization problem; this is the first positive result on this classical question for the last 30 years.   The work on low-dimensional manifolds includes work with Diarmuid Crowley on knotted surfaces in S^4.   Work with Jonathan Hillman bridges both high and low-dimensional topology, and is connected with the Borel topological rigidity conjectures for compact aspherical manifolds with boundary, with a focus on dimension four.   We have complete results in dimension four for good fundamental groups, using our classification of the elementary amenable fundamental groups of compact aspherical 4-manifolds.   

 

The research in combinatorics is joint with Laura Anderson.   It involves deep connections between oriented matroids (a combinatorial version of linear algebra), hyperfields (an analogue of fields with multivalued addition), and topologies on finite sets.   This research has been published in the journal Advances in Mathematics.   

 

Project outcomes connected with broader impacts include graduate education, conference organization, and expository work.   In addition to (almost) constant graduate mentoring and reading courses, I have advised two students who received their Ph.D. during the grant period: Hailiang Hu and Kelvin Guilbault.   Funds from the grant funded research opportunities for these and other students.   I co-organized a large NSF-funded, two-week, research conference in Australia: Topology of Manifolds: Interactions between high and low dimensions.  This event had an interdisciplinary and educational focus.   Participants and speakers were chosen with both mathematical and diversity considerations in mind.   In terms of exposition, I gave two mini-courses (one in Australia and one in Germany) for younger mathematicians.  I published (jointly) a list of problems in manifold theory.   Finally, work continues on the second edition of my book with Paul Kirk: Lecture Notes in Algebraic Topology.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2021
Modified by: James F Davis
por.por_txt_cntn:
This grant funded successful research in several areas of theoretical mathematics: geometric topology, combinatorics, and homological algebra.   Some of the funded research has already been published and some of it is in the process of being prepared for publication.   

 

The research in geometric topology is connected with manifold theory: both high and low-dimensional manifolds.   The work on high-dimensional manifold is joint with Wolfgang Lueck; one paper has been published in the prestigious journal Communication on Pure and Applied Mathematics.  We have a second paper on the Nielsen Realization problem; this is the first positive result on this classical question for the last 30 years.   The work on low-dimensional manifolds includes work with Diarmuid Crowley on knotted surfaces in S^4.   Work with Jonathan Hillman bridges both high and low-dimensional topology, and is connected with the Borel topological rigidity conjectures for compact aspherical manifolds with boundary, with a focus on dimension four.   We have complete results in dimension four for good fundamental groups, using our classification of the elementary amenable fundamental groups of compact aspherical 4-manifolds.   

 

The research in combinatorics is joint with Laura Anderson.   It involves deep connections between oriented matroids (a combinatorial version of linear algebra), hyperfields (an analogue of fields with multivalued addition), and topologies on finite sets.   This research has been published in the journal Advances in Mathematics.   

 

Project outcomes connected with broader impacts include graduate education, conference organization, and expository work.   In addition to (almost) constant graduate mentoring and reading courses, I have advised two students who received their Ph.D. during the grant period: Hailiang Hu and Kelvin Guilbault.   Funds from the grant funded research opportunities for these and other students.   I co-organized a large NSF-funded, two-week, research conference in Australia: Topology of Manifolds: Interactions between high and low dimensions.  This event had an interdisciplinary and educational focus.   Participants and speakers were chosen with both mathematical and diversity considerations in mind.   In terms of exposition, I gave two mini-courses (one in Australia and one in Germany) for younger mathematicians.  I published (jointly) a list of problems in manifold theory.   Finally, work continues on the second edition of my book with Paul Kirk: Lecture Notes in Algebraic Topology.

					Submitted by: James F Davis
